verb.description: Ascertain the size, amount, or degree of (something) by using an instrument or device marked in standard units or by comparing it with an object of known size.
examples: the amount of water collected is measured in pints
they will measure up the room and install the cabinets

verb.description: Estimate or assess the extent, quality, value, or effect of (something)
examples: it is hard to measure teaching ability

verb.description: Travel over (a certain distance or area)
examples: we must measure twenty miles today

noun.description: A plan or course of action taken to achieve a particular purpose.
examples: children were evacuated as a precautionary measure

noun.description: A standard unit used to express the size, amount, or degree of something.
examples: a furlong is an obsolete measure of length

noun.description: A certain quantity or degree of something.
examples: the states retain a large measure of independence

noun.description: The rhythm of a piece of poetry or a piece of music.

phrases: The previous night had rendered me absolutely useless, as I had stayed up all night working on the next-to-last chapter of my book, and was exhausted beyond measure.
It was perverse beyond measure, but it was not selfish.
He had been rich beyond measure, and suddenly he was poor.
The idea that she might kill him terrified him beyond measure.
origin: Middle English (as a noun in the senses moderation, instrument for measuring, unit of capacity): from Old French mesure, from Latin mensura, from mens- measured, from the verb metiri.
